@andrewmeows all they're doing is moving the practical stuff to the start of the course, women currently still do it, just later
@andrewmeows if they're being held to same standard, i dont see that as discrimination, a lower gpa to get into course for men would be
@andrewmeows or it could just be more graduates in total, but higher % of men, considering he's saying theres a shortage
@andrewmeows it might encourage the people that would've dropped out after 1st year to stick around
@andrewmeows im happy with individuals following their personal preferences, rather than trying to get quotas of 50/50
@andrewmeows differences in personality and brain development is fact. im saying its not affirmative action/discrimination to change course
@andrewmeows it was hyperbole, but in the general pop we can see there are more part time or not working women, same in med and law
@andrewmeows i dont think theres anything wrong with exposure to practical stuff first. both sexes still go through the same course
@andrewmeows mathematically, if they work the same hours up to 30, comparing from 30 onwards will give you better picture of the differences
@andrewmeows but it seemed obvious to me he was talking about hours worked rather than the quality of the veterinarian
@andrewmeows the gap would be larger than 37 vs 45 hours if you started measuring at age 30-35 rather than all ages.
@andrewmeows women in 1st world countries already can do whatever they want. some people dont seem to accept that differences exist
@andrewmeows part culture, part biology. social justice types tend to ignore biology, and assume all differences stem from oppression

@andrewmeows genes and hormones have huge influence on behaviour, if we're gonna compare the 2 sexes, you have to generalize
@andrewmeows evo psych: men have stronger incentive to seek status and $, women value work-life balance more, consistent across cultures
